section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Anna McQuinn, illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw
section-block.rac_book_summary: Lola wants to plant a garden. With a lot of planning, help, and hard work, her flowers grow! There are many opportunities to find patterns, count, and discuss height as Lola’s garden comes to life.

section-block.rac_body-text: Hold up four Connecting Cubes in one hand and count them. Then, split them evenly between your two hands. Each hand has the same number of cubes! Count again.
Recite and discuss the Mary, Mary rhyme at the beginning of the book: This is an old nursery rhyme. It’s about a girl who plants a garden! Let’s say it together.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw.
You know that Lala loves all sorts of books and that she loves to look for numbers and shapes in story books like this one!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read: What is one thing Lola puts in her garden?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book, pausing to discuss the prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
Focus on Operations: Use Connecting Cubes to represent items on the page as you talk about equal groups.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Lola’s favorite poem is the rhyme we just learned! We are going to read about what Lola decides to have in her own garden.
Lola is choosing flowers to plant in her garden. How is her mom helping her? (MB)
Let’s count Lola’s books. Who can separate the six books into two equal groups?
section.rac_body-text: Use Connecting Cubes to represent the six books.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Lola is buying seeds for her garden. What will they grow into?
It looks like Lola planted two rows of seeds. How can we separate the two rows into two equal groups?
What is happening? What are green shoots?
Lola hung silver bells in her garden, just like in the poem! How many bells do you see on this page? How many bells will be in each group if we separate the six bells into two equal groups?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What is one thing Lola puts in her garden?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Lola puts seeds in her garden.
Lola puts shells in her garden.
Lola puts Mary Mary in her garden.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about decorating a garden as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Lola put shells in her garden or books in her garden?
There are sh____ (shells) in Lola’s garden.
There are shells in Lola’s garden.
If you had a garden, what would you put in it?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children develop proper sentence structure mainly through repetition. As you read, have children repeat possessive sentences and pronouns after you: This is Lola’s garden. She planted it. Encourage children to answer questions in complete sentences, pausing to model correct subject-verb agreement and plurals when necessary.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Try to Help Others

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We all have times when we need a little help. Trying to help others is a great way to show that you care! When you notice someone is sad, you can help by offering to play with them. When you see someone has lost something, you can help them find it. You can even draw or make something for someone you love to help them smile! How have you helped someone today?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. We will look for ways the characters help each other.
Clifford loves to help others! He likes to read books in which the characters help each other. That way, he can learn new ways to help his friends.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Patterns: Pause to point out patterns in the book. Challenge children to continue each pattern.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is Lola’s mom helping Lola do in this picture? Who helps you read your favorite books? (MB)
I see a pattern on Lola’s dress! The flowers are in this order: red, yellow, red, yellow. Which color comes next?
Lola and her mom are making a plan. What do you think they are planning to do?
Lola has to wait for her flowers to grow. Waiting can be hard! What would you do to help Lola have fun while she waits? (MB)
I see a pattern in Lola’s flowers! They are planted in this order: pink, pink, orange, pink, pink, orange. The last flower is orange. Which color comes next?
What is Lola’s dad helping her do in this picture? What else do you think Lola could use help with in her garden? (MB)
How many bells are on this page? Let’s count. Now, let’s count the pink flowers. Are there the same number of bells as flowers?

section.rac_body-text: Have children help you do some research! Tell children that later this week, they will start to grow their own plants. Before that, you need to find out the best ways to care for a plant. Ask children to help you do online research to learn how to grow and care for a lima bean plant. Guide children to safely use the digital tools you have available. If you are not able to use the Internet, refer to informational texts.
Transcribe children’s speech as they discuss and count the steps to grow a lima bean plant.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Empathy is an important step in children’s ability to help others. Children need to be able to identify that others need help and know what kind of help others need. As you read, help children find hints as to when characters may be sad or struggling to do something alone. Model thinking aloud about what you could do to help. (Denham, 2003)

section-block.rac_body-text: Hold up two Connecting Cube towers, one with six cubes and one with two. Think aloud as you compare their heights. Remind children that size can be relative.
Lead children on a “size hunt.” Guide children to look around the room for the tallest item they can find. Then have them look for the shortest item.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw.
Lala loves reading books that tell a story. She is excited to read the story today and think about height!
There are lots of ways to care for a garden. As we read today, think about this question: What is one thing Lola does to care for her garden?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s look closer at the yellow flowers on the pages in Lola’s book. Are the flowers in the picture tall? How can you tell?
Lola is making a flower book. How many flowers are in her book?
Lola is making one more flower. How many flowers will be in Lola’s book when she adds a new one?
Making a flower book is a lot of work! How is Lola’s mom helping her? What could you do to help Lola? (MB)
Lola’s seeds grew into tiny green shoots! Tiny is another way to say small or short. How can you tell that the shoots are short?
Which flowers on this page are short? Which flowers are tall? How can you tell? Can you find something else on this page that is short?
Is Lola shorter or taller than her dad? Why does Lola need her dad’s help to hang the bells? (MB)
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What is one thing Lola does to care for her garden?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk to discuss the question. Then, use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about what Lola does for her garden.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Lola pull from the garden?
What else can you do to care for a garden?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children develop an understanding of measurement by using words that describe size, such as big, small, tall, and short. Practicing with these words builds an awareness that different items have different dimensions. Have children find and describe different-sized items in the book and in real life.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children play “Duck, Duck, Goose,” using the words “Giant, Giant, Jack.” Ask whether children are familiar with the story of Jack and the Beanstalk, and work with children to retell it. Review the characteristics of a giant before beginning to read the Big Chart of Big Ideas.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Jack and the Beanstalk. It is a fairy tale about a boy who grows a magical plant.
Lola Plants a Garden and Jack and the Beanstalk both focus on growing plants. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Lola Plants a Garden book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can we help plants grow?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Caring for Plants
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, pausing to ask questions and talk about relative heights.
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: Jack traded the cow for the beans.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the cow in this picture taller or shorter than Jack? How can you tell?
Jack and his mom do not have much money for food. What could you do to help a friend who is hungry? (MB)
The beans grew into a giant beanstalk! How tall do you think the beanstalk is? Is it taller than a house? Taller than a mountain?
Jack climbed very high. What do you think he will find at the top?
The giants are eating dinner. How many plates are on the table? Let’s count.
Is Jack taller or shorter than the cake? How can you tell? Do you think the giants will find him?
Why did Jack steal the goose?

section.rac_body-text: Have children grow their own beanstalk! Gather clear containers, cotton balls, water, and dried lima beans. Have children hold their beans and describe what they see. Then, guide children to fill their container with cotton balls and place several beans around the edge. Add just enough water to moisten the cotton balls. Encourage children to watch as their plants grow taller over the next week.
Provide a writing prompt about the steps to growing a plant, and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children at this age are already scientific thinkers. They perform their own experiments, like testing which way a ball will roll or how much water can fill a cup. Part of scientific thinking is making predictions. Each day, invite children to predict what will happen to their bean plants. Encourage them to check for changes every morning, and discuss what they see.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Our earth | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to describe what they remember reading, learning, and doing this week. Guide children to use the past tense, pointing out when a word does not have a regular ending: When we talk about something that already happened, we usually add -ed. We planted seeds! But the word read is different. We didn’t readed Jack and the Beanstalk–we read it. What else did we do this week?
Invite children to act out a garden scene. Have children pretend to be flowers, insects, or gardeners. Ask children to show you whether they are tall or short.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Lola Plants a Garden one more time this week.
Who remembers if this book tells a story or teaches us information?
We have learned many ways to care for plants. When we read today, think about this question: What steps can you take to plant and care for a garden?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is Lola taller or shorter than the stack of books? How can you tell?
Lola’s mom is making a list of flowers to plant. Let’s pretend to hold a notebook and write a list of flowers for our garden.
How many people do you see in the background of this picture? Let’s count! If we start with this person, are there still three?
Let’s pretend to help Lola plant seeds. Crouch down and push each seed into the dirt. What else could we help Lola do in her garden? (MB)
Who can point to the snail in this picture? Is the snail tall or short? How can you tell?
Let’s pretend to help Lola pull up weeds! Reach down to dig them up, and pull hard!
How many butterflies are in this picture? Let’s count. Does it matter which butterfly we count first, or will there still be four?
Let’s pretend to be butterflies in Lola’s garden! Flap your wings and find a flower to land on.
Lola made cupcakes for her friends! Are her cupcakes shorter or taller than the teapot? How can you tell?
Let’s all clap for Lola! She grew a beautiful garden!
What steps can you take to plant and care for a garden?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Then, ask several children to share with the group.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can plant seeds in the ground.
I can pull weeds to help my plants grow.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about planting and caring for a garden.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you care for a garden by planting seeds or rocks?
I can care for a garden by planting s____ (seeds).
I can care for a garden by planting seeds.
Where would you plant a garden of your own?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Past-tense verbs can be tricky for multilingual learners, particularly when they are irregular. Model several sentences before asking children to contribute their own, using words that clearly denote time: Yesterday, we planted a beanstalk. Repeat irregular past-tense verbs often to help children become familiar with them.
